So the next phase of the bitcoin game is political, explicitly so. I imagine we're going to see Congress getting heavily involved, and debates about a Federal ban. They'll debate reining it in by force in 2018, but probably not act until 2019 or 2020. That's my best guess.

Mining was meant to be distributed. The Bitcoin security method collapsed when the number of significant miners collapsed. But the distributed mining strategy also gave us a form of (fairly) basic income. ASIC mining broke bitcoin really, really badly, I'm sorry to say.

So the question is this: how big can bitcoin get before US Federal action is required to defend the dollar? Is there enough money in the ecosystem to buy enough influence to delay that action? Is there a strategy to coordinate that defence? Big games now. Dangerous ones. It's on
If the mining is decentralized, bitcoin is UBI for computer owners.

Bitcoin was intended to be a basic income system. Mining was meant to happen on your laptop as you slept. When mining became driven by capital in the form of ASIC manufacturing, the "one person one share" intention of the original design collapsed into centralization. https:// twitter.com/piratekp/statu s/939340573877530624 …

Nobody on the financial regulator side wants to kill the goose that lays the golden egg. But the forces of fiat currency have a lot on their side - not just guns and bombs, but clear arguments that bitcoin is compromised by miner centralization and similar factors. https:// twitter.com/saifedean/stat us/939228546836389893 …

It's a mess. This is what revolutions look like, for sure. Enormous redistributions of wealth. Two paradigms colliding. But to hold, bitcoin would have to be actually distributed, not run by miners and massively concentrated in a few (lucky) hands. It's unstable, profoundly so. https:// twitter.com/saifedean/stat us/939228546836389893 …
